topic.title: Zeronet and Favicons
topic.body: So, I'm a little curious, I've been lurking around here for a while and only just started really getting active on here, and I can't help but notice that every zite seems to have the same zeronet logo in the favicon except Zerome that has it's own. I'm curious as to how that was achieved, as you'd think more zites would change the favicon if they'd knew how. Anyone has a clue?

topic.title: ZeroTalk limit
topic.body: I'm getting dangerously close to the limit, so I sent a ZeroMail to @nofish but I've yet to have a response or the limit raised, is there some other way I can get it raised?

> Name.YO is as centralized as ZeroID -- not everyone likes it, but it's the only way to make Name.YO free.

So, I guess the question with this is, would it be "decentralizable" the same way the clearnet dns is, aka say clone zite, and that way offer your own dns site/zeronet domain registrar, and have them communicate with each other so that you don't have to use one centralized dns source but can instead use many? It would be worth looking into this.

I think this is way better than Namecoin's .bit, in a way, it is easy to use and free, whereas I've looked at namecoin for the past few weeks and there's almost no exchanges, it seems to have lost the popularity it once had. Stuff that used to integrate with it rarely even work.

Not promising perfect uptime since it's on my computer but I'm running my computer practically 24/7 and only reboot once every few days, and that's usually a relatively quick thing to do, so it should be up near 24/7.

I'm mirroring what I asked on ZeroMe cause idk if you've seen it there for some reason, you were right about BackgroundProcessing being the master branch rather than the py3 branch, even though I was sure I'd told git to checkout on the py3 branch, but whatever, I fixed that and restarted zeronet, no more of that error, however now while trying to register, I'm getting this from KxoNetwork in my Zeronet console: `[KxoNetwork] Unknown command: register` any idea what's the problem there?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1048_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): That's not a bug, that's a feature (c). register command is sent first, it's handled by superadmin registrars (i.e. me and Krixano). In case we're both offline, the client sends register2 in a few seconds, and that command is then handled by other registrars.

Hmm, it's been a while now and the KxoID register page doesn't tell me I'm registered and the console doesn't have anything else about sending a register2 command, any clue why that might be?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1049_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Are you sure you don't have an account already?

doing that now

still hasn't said anything besides unknown command: register in the console, and the page keeps loading the registration... are people in the zeronet network who don't have the peermessage plugin still broadcasting peermessages? cause that might be why it doesn't work?
It's doing this: https://files.catbox.moe/heys7t.png decrementing the 'to:' each time
I opened about 15 of them and so far all of them say this: `result: { error: "Invalid message for site 1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P: ping" }`
I'm gonna try that out now

Nope? I'm using the Zeronet 0.7.1 (rev 4214) with Tor: Available mode and over a hundred trackers cuz I figured the more trackers the better.

Yep I'm retrying in a second.
Oh it worked this time around, ty

it should be started already? I believe I have the 0background.py and 0config.json files already in my KxoNet website folder, unless I need to run said py file? -- on that topic, I can't help but notice that the content of the 0config-level2.json file in that folder is identical to the content of the 0config.json file you had me make xD

1568783263_1Q5f5jQxn2duHpJCCdWhYCkeM8pGa.body:
Nice extension.

@GitCenter is that zhttp protocol implemented at all, as in, could it be used instead of `http://127.0.0.1:43110/`?

There is a likely issue with using the .bit TLD as the gif shows, the .bit TLD is also usable in clearnet using Namecoin's blockchain as a DNS, instantly redirecting all .bit domains to zeronet's makes reaching the clearnet sites difficult, as in you need to manually go through the blockchain to find the associated IP to visit it as this extension instantly redirects you to the zeronet site if it exists?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1043_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Nope, it's just a proposal.

That's sad, it would be convenient if it was a thing.

> [sprite1ww](#comment_1_1Q5f5jQxn2duHpJCCdWhYCkeM8pGagUDdp): Is there an easy way of determining if a *.bit domain is in the ZeroNet or in the Namecoin side of things?

In the Namecoin blockchain (I'm not exactly an expert on it since I still haven't had the opportunity to get any Namecoins), you can see the content of the domain names. According to [this page](https://wiki.namecoin.org/index.php?title=Register_and_Configure_.bit_Domains), you can find out what the domain points to in both clearnet and zeronet inside the content of said names. Inside the blockchain, domains are marked as d/domain instead of domain.bit. The content appears to be a JSON object containing just about whatever you want to put in, however, they 'standardized' certain things, such as the following:
For clearnet:
`{"ns": ["ns0.web-sweet-web.net", "ns1.web-sweet-web.net", "ns0.xname.org"]}` - An object with the "ns" array delegates anything that isn't before that array in the object to the listed name servers, it also supports IP addresses but it isn't a recommended use of the DNS delegation
`{"ip":"1.2.3.4", "map": {"demo": {"ip":"1.2.3.5"}, "*": {"ip":"1.2.3.4"}}}` - An object with "ip" point domain.bit towards the ip in question, subdomains are in the map object, so in this example, domain.bit points to 1.2.3.4, demo.domain.bit points to 1.2.3.5, and every other subdomains point to 1.2.3.4.
`{"translate": "bitcoin.org", "ns": ["1.2.3.4", "1.2.3.5"]}` - An object with "translate" will translate the change the domain to the value before doing the delegation, in this example, if you looked up foo.domain.bit, it would change it to foo.bitcoin.org before looking it up in the delegated name servers.
For zeronet:
```
{
  "zeronet": {
  "": "1EU1tbG9oC1A8jz2ouVwGZyQ5asrNsE4Vr",
  "subdomain": "1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8",
  "subdomain2": "1TaLk3zM7ZRskJvrh3ZNCDVGXvkJusPKQ" }
} 
```
You would put a zeronet object inside the domain's object and inside give each key-value pair where the key is the subdomain and the value is the bitcoin public address of the website.

The issue as I see it for your extension is that it is possible for someone to have both a zeronet and a clearnet .bit site and your extension would forcefully pull you into the zeronet one even if you intended to see the clearnet one. I assume you could either host or find a server online that offers .bit DNS lookup through an API that you could use in your extension to figure out if the .bit address has a zeronet object within it, but that still keeps the problem of there being also a clearnet site with the same .bit address.

That's unfortunate., it would be nice for people to use it. I'm probably gonna use it on my zites, probably using a resized copy of my avatar until I can be bothered to actually make some.

> [randomshits](#comment_127_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): If my memory serves me correctly, the site owner only needs to include the favicon.ico file in the site's root directory and sign the site for the zeronet client to seamlessly apply the favicon.

My 2 zites currently have a `"favicon": "img/favicon.png"` in the content.json file and said file in the implied location, and it works fine. Doubt anyone will bother going to the effort of making a favicon.ico file when you can just resize any image to 16x16, drop it in the zite's folder and add a line with it's location in the content.json and sign the change.

1568854490_1MfahbRQx2DvKRccN57nhFZvYmfir.body: I'm betting the answer to this is no one has tried and you'd likely need to add something to transmission-daemon to make it download zeronet content.

1568856272_1MfahbRQx2DvKRccN57nhFZvYmfir.body:
> It says signing successfull, publish failed, content is available, no peers. 

You have your answer right there. No peers have downloaded/visited your site, so while you can sign it successfully, publishing fails because no one downloads the update. If someone were to visit the site, so long as you are online, they will receive the site from you, so the content is available. In other words, what you need is to make people visit your site, then publishing will succeed, of course, you don't *have to* do so if you want to keep it private for now, as I was planning on doing as long as I didn't have anything interesting to offer, until I decided that keeping mine private was less important than grabbing my domain names from the name.yo DNS.

1568942181_1KJWLBhkwmtbUH2zhcbfWinQK9kJ4.body: You should try being behind 7 tor

1568982640_1D9mg5Mzk96FBLEkjCxabcydfY4Bb.body: NMC is indeed a pain in the ass to acquire nowadays... No functional faucets, very few exchanges that still support it, I'm thinking Namecoin is basically dying at the moment. Especially when I go take a look at the Namecoin forums and there's exactly no activity there.

> [htgozn](#comment_264_1J58Rie679DVSuKB1iDyFFTbzmaMaY2bt2): It died about two years ago, now there are just dung beetles picking at the remains.

That makes me wonder why ZeroNet still supports it, tbh. Name.yo is infinitely better (and making it decentralized in a similar way to KxoID using PeerMessage and BackgroundProcessing would make it even better), and supporting clearnet DNS on ZeroNet using a TXT record that contains the exact same zeronet JSON object as they have you put in the NMC .bit domain would be relatively simple to do.

> [filips](#comment_215_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Which cryptocurrency has functional faucet for mainnet?

The only one that I believe might still work would probably be the main groups of like bitcoin/litecoin/dogecoin and similar, as well as possibly new altcoin that want to try to be relevant but probably won't ever.

> [filips](#comment_216_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Why not support it? Yes, more DNS systems should be supported (see this), but Namecoin should still be one of them. [...]

Why support something that's basically dead at this point in time?

> [filips](#comment_216_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Name.yo is currently not a solution as it is centralized

It is still better than Namecoin in that you do not have to figure out how to obtain some considering how limited the ways to obtain some are. And I mentioned that designing a decentralized version using the same concepts as KxoID uses would be even better. This is I believe the next step Name.yo needs to take, and if it doesn't, I believe someone will make it happen -- possibly myself at some point if no one else rises up to the task by the time I'm ready to get on it.

> [filips](#comment_216_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): without any abuse prevention system

Such a system would go against the philosophy behind decentralized anti-censorship ZeroNet and even cryptocurrencies are based on.

> [filips](#comment_216_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): It should not be using JSON object, but TXT with direct address of ZeroNet site.

Yes, I merely mentioned that it could use a JSON object because it would be easier to set up as it would require less change to the code behind ZeroName to support it if it used the same format that NMC .bit domains use on ZeroNet.

> [filips](#comment_217_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Why not? There is no cost when supporting it. And it is more decentralized when you support two systems instead of just one. [...]

I'm not saying we should immediately drop support for it, I'm simply saying that as ZeroNet grows, it will inevitably grow bloated, as more and more features are added, so we should consider whether keeping Namecoin, a DNS system that is largely dead is worth it, especially since I'm assuming ZeroName requires that someone, likely nofish, runs a full NMC node, which tends to eat system resources and HDD space quite a lot as opposed to other DNS systems. I agree that adding more DNS systems is worth it, but we should still consider if the effort of adding each, or the cost of keeping each is worth "one more additional DNS system".

> [filips](#comment_217_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Name.yo is currently not a solution. When decentralization is added, other problems are fixed and it is added as built-in plugin, then it will be a good solution.

That's where I disagree. It isn't a perfect solution but it is a solution, likely a temporary one until something better is made or until it is improved with at the very least decentralization.

> [filips](#comment_217_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): I mean such abuse that one user would hijack all domains. This is something that good DNS system, even if decentralized, should have (Namecoin and ENS have this solved, but it is solved with paid domains).

This is difficult to do with a free permanent DNS system. Paid domains solve this easily because unless you have infinite money to waste on it, it's not worth doing this type of abuse, but with a free domain, any system you make to prevent this will likely be seen as attempting to prevent people from obtaining domain names, or setting up the basics for that, at least.

> [filips](#comment_217_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): IPFS is using DNSLink which is new standard for linking content from DNS. ZeroNet should also use it. And code from ZeroName should definitely be changed in both cases (and DNS support should be written as another plugin). But it would actually be easier to resolve DNSLink record as JSON [...]

I agree with that, yes.

1569015162_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEG.body:

1569094102_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: I just switched to it -- does this affect KxoID in any way or does it just run as normal after having uninstalled the old one and installed this one instead?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1079_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Nope, it's the same as the old version. It affects neither KxoID nor any other service.

Great.

Also, I'm not quite sure where to ask this, but I was looking at the Zeronet plugins in the old system and I'm wondering what each of the disabled ones do, just to know if it might be worth looking into enabling them, namely:

Bootstrapper - I found some description for it in the folder that says it allows your ZeroNet client to act like a tracker, not sure what would be the point of that unless you tell people to add you to their trackers, and even then, if you don't have a static IP that would be completely useless wouldn't it?
Dnschain - I'm assuming it has something to do with DNS but there's no information on it so idk what it does really.
DonationMessage - Donation-related, unclear what's the point of it though.
Multiuser - Clearly for the zeronet proxies, generally useless otherwise.
StemPort - Unknown.
UiPassword - Unknown.
ZeronameLocal - I'm assuming this is if you want to run a Zeroname clone locally you have to use this and have the Namecoin blockchain downloaded, as well as a full node running, I assume?

> [gitcenter](#comment_1080_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Right, but you can use services such as ddns.net which give you a static domain name for a dynamic IP.

I've tried using some actually, but I'm betting there's some sort of issue somewhere with my router, cause even if I open the port in it and tell it to redirect any traffic in that specific port that I set up a service to use towards my PC, nothing outside sees my PC if my PC doesn't initiate the connection for some reason even if I tell them to use the domain I used with the ddns service I'm using and which port to use, or my public address with the port. I've yet to figure out why that happens, but it keeps leading to me giving up the idea of hosting anything on my PC even though I've been wanting to for some time.

> [filips](#comment_220_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): Dnschain was experimental plugin for Namecoin support before current Zeroname. It used HTTP API from website called Dnschain to get domain details. That website is now dead so plugin is basically useless (although it is still good as example plugin for additional DNS support).

Now this is something that makes me wonder why it's still being distributed with the ZeroNet client if it's literally useless.
To get back on topic of PeerMessage and all, are you planning on doing the same with BackgroundProcessing as well?

1569172866_1LQUzLxUdiuVZKwr7wiqii7GzGs8i.body:
> [randomshits](#comment_147_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): When I migrate my users.json to a new zeronet instance, here is my procedure that works for linux & windows [...]

When I changed OS I personally just copied the entire data folder to an external hdd, changed the OS and set it all up, installed a zeronet instance, dropped the data directory where that instance was installed, and then start up the zeronet instance. Worked perfectly.

> [ratsmack](#comment_77_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qks2SU5): A person should be able to set an expiration time for older comments so that space is reclaimed after a set time.

> [d14na](#comment_94_1EAD2zXkzgJf6M7xQ4jG5FHCxUTez9NJJ4): yes, [...]

That sounds counter-productive to the goal of not being forced to censor oneself, but being forced to delete past posts instead because of an extremely low limit.

> [whitewolf](#comment_49_1APZQJTjc6VivR8kW2YDfaPUFkx8vy43o8): what is the number calculated from? mine said 21.9k when I started typing this post. now it is at 22.2k

I'm guessing K stands for Kilobytes, the amount you're allowed to use in the zite folder.

1569594101_14A3LXiT8D3gtRGJSMG3eMbKDtRPd.body:
> [xan](#comment_14_1ATbMGy3hSpTHeHfkmX6kNRn2kbRT7fTHY): 0net lacks mobile support (I'd say by design).

Incorrect, there exists a mobile 0net app called zeronet-kivy, found [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet-kivy). The problem is that it currently runs a full Zeronet node on your mobile device, which is a rather horrible idea: mobile devices rarely have more than a few GB of storage available, and if they do have more, it's still not something close to what a dedicated PC can have, which means it's bound to run out, and you're also likely to be using the mobile device for something else than Zeronet, meaning you'll use the storage space for other apps as well. This all leads into the fact it hasn't reached the point where it could be called usable cause to do that it would need to be a minimal client that actually signs content locally using the keys and then shoot that off to a random full node for them to propagate it, which full nodes aren't currently designed to do, and ask full nodes to give them the website content when asked for it every time, and then delete it when the website is left or as part of the process to shutdown zeronet. Currently, the best method to use Zeronet from mobile is to use UiPassword on your PC and connect to Zeronet using that, which is to say, it's not a great method, since you need to know some about networking to properly set it up to be accessible for your phone from outside the local network if you intend to use it on the go.

> [arruda](#comment_1_12pxfKmo6ZzL7RM8oYGGmEBCSUBZKzv7Bh): operating with a new form of address encoding that isn't human readable

Hopefully someday we'll get alternative forms of DNS all implemented into Zeronet by default so that problem will be easily fixed.

> [filips](#comment_229_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): See #2049, #2164 and #104 on GitHub.

I know about those but some of them have been open for ages and nothing's been dome about it.

> [k0hlr4bi](#comment_28_1DXjRGbVDrJjUQd4ZzmFF1vvQUvqsgJFkH): Just wait until Article 13 turns clearnet into a wasteland. ZeroNet's usage will skyrocket

implying that people will have heard of zeronet and that they'll be pissed enough by that that they'll quit whatever social network they're addicted to

> [randomshits](#comment_184_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): Let's take a fun scenario of probabilities to see why zeronet has so few users. [...]

- Most people I see on clearnet social networks are upset tbh but won't seek alternatives because no one will follow them.
- I don't think any of them care about that.
- Not many.
- The other darknet alternatives are kinda shit, old and have bad UIs though.
- Probably most, it's not like installing a zeronet bundle and using tor browser with it is particularly difficult.
- This is probably the main problem, some I've seen who visited it kinda stopped using it once they realized there isn't a lot of people here, and even less of their online friends.
- Most, I don't know anyone who cannot speak english in a manner that's understandable.
- I doubt they'd care about that since they do it in the clearnet.

Mobile is probably the biggest issue, yes. Most people who use clearnet social networks rarely use the actual website on a desktop or laptop and instead mostly always use it from their phones.

> [beenotung](#comment_37_1DLBhCccN3MbM5YmzNS2UfBzDkEZkGZtVg): If ordinary users don't feel the pain from their current solution, they won't care to try alternatives.The same reason why Telegram has so low adoption rate compare to WhatsApp, which is the "default" way to communicate among the majority of people I met. They even argue Telegram is "harder" to use or "slower" than WhatsApp. They just don't share the same values with us / me so they're doing perfectly fine from their POV.(I seldom use my phone, so WhatsApp is barely useful to me. They just cannot understand why I would use laptop / PC more often than the phone.)

Well, technically speaking, in terms of privacy, Telegram isn't very much better than WhatsApp. Both are closed source so you can't check if they have backdoors, and both require communications to pass by their central server unless you specify it in Telegram. There are likely way better alternatives but they have even lower adoption rates. Also, no one I know uses WhatsApp personally. People IRL use Facebook Messenger and people I talk to online mostly use Discord. Both of which I personally think are very bad from a security/privacy standpoint.

That means all the other people serving it also need to have a massive amount of space, unless you're willing to rely on one centralized server to do all of it.

> [reichardnixon](#comment_24_16NfWw2hgzGaVcQs35UJySKMf4YP9kZFbr): I am not a fan of this idea. I think we need to focus more on a FB type site.  No censorship. People are always talking about going to "VK" or "minds" but we need a decentralized zn version.

It's not a question of idea, it's kinda how ZeroNet works, either you have everything decentralized in the zite, meaning everyone ends up hosting however much hdd space needed to host every single zite ever, or you have a lightweight website that links to a specific or multiple specific servers that host those zites. That's why implementing a latest top zite content supplier thing wouldn't be very popular. Either it goes against ZeroNet's philosophy or it goes way over what people are willing to share in terms of hardware resources.

> [emmet](#comment_26_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdtUW8hU): I don't get it. Can you explain a bit more what's the difference?

Basically, ZeroNet provides for websites hosted on everyone's (who uses ZeroNet) device. Manyverse provides for ScuttleButt on mobile. ScuttleButt provides a sort of micro-blogging social network where you only host the content of people you follow, and you start with exactly 0 people in your social network, and grow it progressively as you meet and add people to your list. In concept, an interesting idea, in reality, a pretty shitty one, cause, well, if you want to suppress speech, just ban someone from all public nodes (of which there are few) and ask people in those nodes to ban the person from their private node as well, and then the person disappears. This leads to a sort of system where instead of a large global hard/impossible to censor network like ZeroNet is you get essentially a bunch of closed off social networks that only accept people they agree with, an echo chamber essentially. If other people who don't follow the same ideology as the main SB devs decided to make pubs, they wouldn't be allowed on their official pub list, thereby removing the main source of potential users for such a small thing that has such a low user base. If they still managed to get adoption going for that pub in their community, you'd end up with 2 separate networks using the same protocol, because they don't politically agree with each other, and therefore refuse to host each other's content and will block anyone who attempts to link the 2 together in any way. It doesn't offer anything of value, in other words, besides being a closed-off system that is sort of decentralized.

> [sheendocks](#comment_65_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3Xr4aCU): Manyverse is list a social network for mobile (it's a mobile implementation of scuttlebutt which works on desktop too). Essentially, you can connect to people via bluetooth, those on the same wifi, via DHT, or via "pubs" which pull data from lots of users who decide to join (not really sure on how pubs work). Because Manyverse works via bluetooth and the local network it's resist to internet connections been taken offline. Andre Staltz develops it and has made some FAQ videos https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RANVVy9oyXE

Pubs are basically a normal client that somehow offer a permanent invitation code for others to join their network. Public ones post it on a public place like a website, private ones require the owner to give out the code to people they trust. As for Manyverse resisting being offline, that's kinda incorrect, it only resist it if someone else is using it and is invited in your client within bluetooth range or within the same local network (in which case if the local network has lost it's internet connection, so does their, so it's not resisting much at all since anything you put there will only become public to everyone else when one of you finally gets an internet connection back).

> [emmet](#comment_27_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdtUW8hU): Oh, so your point is that it's more geared for local comms rather than Internet based peering? Nice.How about wifi ad hoc networking? Is that possible on phones? [...]

Wifi Ad Hoc Networking is only possible on phones that support it, which very few do, unfortunately.

I'd guess they fight off spam the same way they fight people they disagree with: block their content from your pubs so you stop hosting them and ask others to block them too until they're basically isolated and spamming only themselves?

> [emmet](#comment_28_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdtUW8hU): So there's nothing preventing it from generating lots of new IDs and spamming with that? I guess I'm asking what's the ZeroID equivalent on there.

I think you'd need to delete the app and reinstall it to generate a new ID, not sure cause I haven't actually bothered to look into the code, I just tested it out to see what it was. I guess you could, but then again, I tried using a public invite on both the desktop and the mobile client at the same time, and one failed, not cause the invite is one use, but for some reason it won't work twice in a few minutes, so I'm betting this could be their solution. Maybe they're simply rate-limiting each IP, but like I said, I didn't look into the code.

1603122234_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_1392_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): You know, I've always believed the grass is always greener but I had some hope that not the entire Earth is a pile of morons. Yet seeing it's the same in America is disgusting.

"The grass is always greener on the other side" isn't a saying that you should believe the other side is better but rather that both sides are complete shit and looking from one side to the other it always seems like the other is objectively 200% better even though it isn't.

As for mental health, that's something I can't really help with since I have similar issues. As everyone says, diet, sunlight, talking with people, exercising, sleeping well and all that crap is supposed to help, but at the same time, I get what you mean that when you look outside online communities of like-minded individuals, it's incredibly hard to feel happy as you see people act like complete idiots, and react in stupid ways to things that should be really fucking obvious. One thing I always get reminded of is that if the average IQ of humans is 100, then half of them (hopefully me included) are above 100, and the other half below. Also, the IQ of crowds is like -100, no matter what the average IQ of all the individuals in the crowd is. Crowds are dumb as fuck.

Anyways, I get you, as I was here like idk a year ago or so, disappeared for a while and am back now. Thing is, I wish changing all the things mentioned above was all I need to get rid of my mental health issues, but the issue is all of them require motivation to first do these things to get better but as my own mental health issue includes the symptom of practically always being unmotivated to do anything, I haven't actually managed to do much about any of it.

As for Ownership Transferal in cases where mental health is an issue, that's a little bit more complicated, git is kinda great at making sure you can't delete stuff without being able to undo the deletion, but the thing is, it requires at least one person to keep an up to date git repository of everything you wish to keep safe, and that's a whole lot harder to do. Things that automatically Sync properly, like say, Syncthing, don't have a proper functional git-like system of keeping history of versions, which means simply deleting the content of the folder would propagate to anyone else who's Synced to it as long as they're online, and would require them to actually maintain some external means of backing up the Synced content even though the whole point of syncing directories between machines is usually for the purpose of having a backup if for some reason one device dies. This makes things a bit awkward. I tried at one point to use git on a syncthing directory and if that wasn't hell to deal with, idk what is.

Point is, there isn't really an easy way to do this. Like it's been said, the current way would be to shoot over the users.json file through either ZeroMail or GPG encrypted email or some similar thing. But that doesn't help with things like zites that aren't a git directory meaning one could go in there and revert changes later or plugins that are entirely out of ZeroNet where if you don't diligently pull daily you might miss a change and then suddenly have everything wiped on the next update or something.

1617149531_16badkisTTGDcQf3YmZ9ra8b9Pnha.body: The only remotely political ideology I hold that I'd share is my belief in free speech absolutism. Which I describe as the belief that no entity should be allowed to censor speech in any way. The second you allow exceptions to it, the easier it becomes to find ways around it. A good example would be the US's 1st amendment, it only forces governmental organizations to not censor speech, this means that essentially defacto public spaces (such as twitter and youtube, for which the alternatives are so rarely used that they're essentially a monopoly) which are managed by private companies that can and do take political sides and censor opposing speech. This is a failure with free speech as the US implements it, it did not foresee the possibility that someday "public spaces" where political debates would be held could be privately owned, allowing for censorship.

1620169498_14EvrR9QiEpqhQyZDFiftdgAXzNQ1.body:
Honestly, you should self-host your ZeroNet instance, using a clear net proxy is kind of dumb and defeats the point. The point being to control your shit and have no one be able to censor it, however, a public clear net proxy means the proxy providers can likely access everyone who uses it's users.json, and therefore modify any zite you have and sign it as if it was yours.

If it is YOUR clear net proxy that you own however, then you should theoretically be able to update it yourself. I believe (don't quote me on that) that 0.6.x and earlier versions are python2-only and version 0.7.x and higher are python3-only. It likely requires manual intervention from whoever owns the proxy. I'm a bit surprised however that there even still exists a proxy using this old a version since 0.7.x has been a thing for at least 2 years now, if not more.

1622430449_1Fs7oXqGMju27ZzXFFJn4dLt11yrb.body: That's literally impossible by virtue of how zeronet works.
